lexUnit.name: whistle.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: emit or produce a whistle

sentence.text: It kept whistling every now and then . "
Geoffrey leaned back in his chair and whistled softly .
Cranston knelt down next to them and whistled softly through his teeth .
He was glad she was happy and whistled softly to himself as he tied his tie .
Lucie whistled sharply to catch her attention , then beckoned her over to stand beside him .
He knew that he still whistled sometimes , but the bogeyman could not scare him any more .
Arty whistled cheerfully as he pretended to write .
His microphone whistled a little and Sally winced in embarrassment .
He whistled mechanically at the back view of a girl waiting to cross the intersection , though of late girls seemed to have lacked their usual charm for him .
He pulled his cap down over his eyes but the wind whistled bitterly through his ears .
They faced each other , their breath coming in gasps , while , oblivious to the humans on the patio , two hummingbirds whistled as they nestled together in the branches of a scarlet hibiscus .
Manville whistled through his teeth .
Presently , he heard the breath whistle in her throat , a gasp , a tiny groan .
He walked along the road , hands in pockets , whistling like a blackbird .
If I whistled , it would come back to me and rest on my shoulder again .
He whistled , tunelessly .
A lot of people clapped and whistled .
The kettle began to whistle , breaking into her train of thought .
Ember whistled , thin and high .
Somewhere ahead in the crags of Kielderhead Moor a hawk was whistling , a piercing sound in the lonely valley , overlain for a few heart-stopping moments by the snarl of a jet .
The tree frogs whistled -- three urgent calls on a rising scale , one to another , again and again .
The kettle whistled , and she made herself some recaff .
